bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, August 23, 1923

div1.p: Connor seeks Carter's advice on whether or not to suspend the yellow fever campaign in Mexico after twelve disease-free months.

August 23, 1923
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Doctor Russell is here in Mexico reviewing the
work of the Comision Especial contra Fiebre Amarilla.

The question as to the interval of time after
the appearance of the last confirmed case of yellow
fever before considering an area free of the infection
has come up for discussion.

My thought on this question has been that if the
area has remained free of the infection for a period
of twelve consecutive months and more especially if
active anti-larvae measures have been carried on that
we could regard the area as free and suspend work.

Recently Doctor White intimates that it is
quite probable that yellow fever has been in constant
existence in the Bucaramanga-Cucuta area in Columbia for
ten years. The warning implied in Doctor White's lett-
-er has raised the doubt in my as to wisdom of let-
ing go of Mexico after an interval of one year's free-
dom from the infection.

Have you known of an instance where yellow fever
continued in an area unrecognized for as long a period
as ten years, this presumes that the infection was in a
mild type of the disease.

I am recommending to Doctor Russell that this
years yellow fever budget for Mexico be continued thru
1924 and in the event that the I. H.B does not partici-
pate in yellow fever activities in Mexico next year I
am suggesting to the Departamento de Salubridad to extend
their anti-malaria measures to include a house to house
inspection on a six day cycle in the important centers
such as, Merida, Veracruz, Tampico, Panuco and possibly
Tuxpam.

The question I would like to have your views on
is this, are we justified in suspending yellow fever
activities in Mexico after an interval of twelve consec-
utive months of supposed freedom, based on data collected, from the
